importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the plane crash, which occurred on September 18, 2025, is central to understanding the timeline and context of the incident.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeframe from September 18 to October 20, 2025, covers the period from the crash to the release of the preliminary NTSB report, highlighting the investigation process and public response.

keyTakeAways: Brett James, a Grammy-winning songwriter known for collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, was killed in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, in Franklin, North Carolina.

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) preliminary report indicates the plane entered a 'tightening spiral' during flight and crashed after James failed to change his radio frequency to the common traffic advisory frequency, despite being instructed to do so.
James had requested a visual approach to runway 7, which was approved by air traffic control, and announced his position at 6,800 feet with a planned 360-degree turn.
The aircraft, a Cirrus SR22T, flew over the runway and descended into a left turn before entering the spiral and crashing; no mechanical issues were found in the wreckage.
The incident raises concerns about pilot communication protocols, radio frequency adherence, and the potential risks of miscommunication in visual approaches without constant monitoring.

namedEntities.name: Brett James
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Grammy-winning songwriter and music industry collaborator
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Brett James is the central figure in the incident, as he was piloting the plane that crashed and died along with two others. His prominence in the music industry makes the event a significant cultural and public tragedy.

namedEntities.name: National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. federal agency responsible for investigating transportation accidents
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The NTSB issued the preliminary report on the crash, providing official findings and contributing to public understanding of the cause of the accident.

namedEntities.name: Cirrus SR22T
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A type of single-engine, general aviation aircraft
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The specific model of the aircraft involved in the crash, which shows the vehicle used in the flight and is part of the technical context of the accident.

namedEntities.name: Franklin, North Carolina
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city located about 270 miles southeast of Nashville
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The crash site, which provides geographic context for the incident and helps identify the location of the tragedy.

namedEntities.name: Runway 7
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A designated runway at an airport, used for aircraft landings and takeoffs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The intended landing runway, which was part of the flight plan and shows where the pilot was attempting to land.

namedEntities.name: Taylor Swift
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global pop and country music superstar
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James collaborated with Swift, making him a prominent figure in the broader music industry and increasing public awareness of his death.

namedEntities.name: Bon Jovi
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James worked with Bon Jovi, highlighting his extensive influence across multiple music genres and industries.

namedEntities.name: Keith Urban
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country music artist and songwriter
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James collaborated with Keith Urban, reinforcing his reputation as a top-tier songwriter in the country music scene.

namedEntities.name: Kenny Chesney
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James co-wrote Kenny Chesney’s 'Out Last Night,' which is a key example of his songwriting success and industry recognition.

namedEntities.name: Carrie Underwood
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James co-wrote 'Jesus, Take the Wheel' for Carrie Underwood’s debut album, marking a pivotal point in his career and linking him to a major music success story.

namedEntities.name: Common Traffic Advisory Frequency (CTAF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A radio frequency used by pilots to broadcast position when no tower control is present
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: James failed to tune to the CTAF, leading to a breakdown in communication with air traffic control, a critical factor in the accident.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Grammy-winning songwriter Brett James, known for his collaborations with Taylor Swift, Bon Jovi, Keith Urban, and Kenny Chesney, died in a plane crash on September 18, 2025, near Franklin, North Carolina. The National Transportation Safety Board’s preliminary report indicates that James failed to change his radio frequency to the common traffic advisory frequency, despite being instructed to do so. The plane, a Cirrus SR22T, entered a 'tightening spiral' after descending and turning, ultimately crashing. No mechanical issues were found, and the incident underscores the importance of proper radio communication in aviation, especially during visual approaches.
title: Songwriter Brett James’ plane entered a ‘tightening spiral’ before crashing, the NTSB said in a preliminary report
